results.title: The Son's room = La Stanza Del Figlio
results.creator_credit: Nanni Moretti, Angelo Barbagallo, Telepiu, Sacher Film, Radiotelevisione Italiana, Canal+ and Bac Films (France)
results.brief_description: This melancholic and intimate Italian drama tackles the subject of death of a child and the catastrophic after effects on family. Giovanni is a successful psychoanalyst residing in a quaint seaside town. He has a warm and tender relationship with his wife, and two adolescent children - son, Andrea and daughter, Irene. This family is loving and understanding, interested in one another and well adjusted. Focussing on Giovanni, he is depicted as affectionate and caring even as he worries about Andrea’s attitude and troubles at school. This idyllic calm is shattered when Andrea accidentally drowns and the remainder of the film examines how each individual family member adjusts to Andrea’s death, deals with their loss and how the family struggles on as a unit. Internalising his sorrow and guilt, Giovanni plays out endless streams of ‘what-ifs’, whilst his isolation corrodes his relationships with wife and daughter. Part of the appeal of Moretti’s film is his observation of the ordinariness of grief and the moments where it strikes, achieving true pathos and catharsis. Written, directed and starring Moretti, “The Son’s room” is a poignant and compassionate work that is effective and understated as it gently examines the difficulties inherent within mourning and death. Cast includes Nanni Moretti, Laura Morante, Silvio Orlando and Stefano Accorsi.

results.title: Under the sand = Sous le sable [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Francois Ozon, Marc Missonnier, Olivier Delbosc, Haut et Court, Fidelite Productions, Euro Space and Arte France
results.brief_description: French psychological drama starring Charlotte Rampling as Marie Drillon, a woman deeply in love with her husband, Jean, who goes missing one day whilst they are on holiday. The narrative intimately follows Marie’s journey as she grieves over her loss. Unable to cope with the difficulties of grief and implications that he may have committed suicide or fled to escape their mundane marriage, she becomes delusional. Despite all evidence to the contrary, the elegant Marie, an English literary professor, continues to behave as if Jean is alive. She converses with him and is even beset by visions of his presence. In an outstanding performance Rampling adroitly conveys Marie’s weariness and aging, vanity and disillusionment, sexual needs and stubborn denial about her predicament. Ozon’s skill lies in his observation of the everyday - Marie’s world is peppered with the trappings of sophistication, with the elegantly muted clothes and tasteful urbane Parisian surrounds - signifiers for Marie’s inner lifelessness and crushing grief. Unlike the over the top histrionics of “Sitcom” or the gaudy excesses of “Eight women”, Ozon infuses “Under the sand” with a lyrically understated beauty and rare cinematic pathos. Cast includes: Bruno Cremer, Jacques Nolot, Alexandra Stewart, Pierre Vernier, Andree Tainsy and Maya Gaugler. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Vampire hunter D: bloodlust [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Yoshiaki Kawajiri, Taka Nagasawa, Masao Maruyama, Mata Yamamoto, Film Line International and Urban Vision Entertainment
results.brief_description: In this animated horror movie, set in a menacing distant future where the dead haunt the living, a deadly vampire kidnaps a beautiful human woman. Her distraught family offer a huge reward for her rescue - dead or alive. One bounty hunter, Dunpeal, a half-human, half-vampire being, at war with himself, tortured and alone, is hired to retrieve the girl. But a rival group of rescuers, the Marcus siblings, resent Dunpeal’s presence, and plan to use him in order to collect the loot. In his quest, D faces many nasty encounters with murderous semi-human creatures, including a werewolf, a shape-shifter, a phantom queen, and a subculture of human-hating monsters. In Vampire Hunter D: Bloodlust”, the sequel to “Vampire hunter D (1985), the future has the aesthetic of a dystopic, medieval nightmare but the animation is far more sophisticated than in the original. Director Yoshiaki Kawajiri (Wicked City, Animatrix) keeps the action exciting, even if the characterisations are simplistic, and the violent gory animatronics are awe-inspiring in scope, embodying all the qualities of gothic, bloody combat, whilst harking to the model of the eternal outsider, moody and disliked, shunned by society and feared by his enemies.

results.title: The Devil's backbone = El Espinazo del diablo
results.creator_credit: Guillermo del Toro, Pedro Almodovar, Tequila Gang and El Deseo S. A.
results.brief_description: Finding himself in a home for the sons of fallen leftists in the Spanish Civil War, the naive Carlos (Fernando Tielve) discovers the desolate hideaway has more to offer than the ominous unexploded bomb in the centre of the playground. Assigned to the former bed of Santi, he soon encounters a supernatural presence shared by all but mocked with disdain by rival and bully Jaime (Inigo Garces). Meanwhile, Jacinto (Eduardo Noriega) a former resident of the orphanage poses as a janitor and becomes the lover of the headmistress Carmen (Marisa Paredes) to seek out the gold stored for the cause. As the personal history and intimate secrets of the orphanage unravel in front of Carlos’ eyes, Del Toro’s use of the war as a background serves as a political allegory on both the past and future. Cast also includes Federico Luppi, Irene Visedo.

results.title: Last orders
results.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Elizabeth Robinson, Winchester Films, Scala Productions and MPB
results.brief_description: Effortlessly moving between World War II and contemporary London, “Last Orders” is a film about friendship, honour and familial ties. Jack Dodd’s three best friends, and his son (played by Ray Winstone), are taking his ashes from London to Margate for the burial that Jack has demanded. His wife, Amy (Helen Mirren), has refused to go along for the ride: her journey takes the form of bittersweet remembrance of the betrayals, joys and comforts which are part of a lifelong marriage. Schepisi creates a perfectly realistic evocation of both old age and the passionate desires and dreamings of youth. “Last Orders” is in fact a peculiar kind of road movie in which the most important part of the journey is across time, and one in which the characters and personalities of the travellers are much more important than the dour suburbia through which they travel. At the heart of the film is Michael Caine’s Oscar nominated performance as Jack Dodd but he is ably supported by a superlative cast of British character actors. By placing actors such as Caine, Tom Courtenay and David Hemmings in a film about aging, death and grief, Schepisi also creates a loving memorial to the golden age of British cinema - the tough working class films of the early sixties which smashed the genteel pretensions of an earlier British cinema (though gentility was to arise again in the period dramas which now form the backbone of British television). “Last Orders” is based on the award winning novel by Graham Swift.

results.title: The Taking of Pelham one two three
results.creator_credit: Joseph Sargent, Edgar J. Scherick, Gabriel Katzka, Palladium Productions and Palomar Pictures
results.brief_description: A thriller drama of the 70s about a well-planned train hijack of a New York City subway train, Pelham one two three (the name of the train’s starting station and its departure time, 1.23 pm). The highly organised armed gang of four is led by a British ex-mercenary who calls himself Mr Blue (Robert Shaw). Their demand is for $1 million in cash from the City of New York in exchange for 18 hostages contained in the first car which has been detached from the rest of the hijacked train. If their demand is not met within one hour, then one hostage will die for every minute the money is late. In the firing line is Lt Zachary Garber (Walter Matthau) of the Transit Authority Police who has the unenviable task of negotiating directly with Mr Blue and the heavy weight of the hostages’ lives in his hands. Panic and chaos ensue, and lives are lost, as frantic efforts are made to raise the cash. The plot has an interesting twist and the characters are made up of an eclectic mix. Based on the novel by John Gody with screenplay by Peter Stone, the film although full of suspense and drama laced with the odd moment of humour, unfortunately falls down when some of this humour involves racial slurring. Cast also includes Martin Balsam (Mr Green), Hector Elizondo (Mr Grey) and Earl Hindman (Mr Brown) and Lee Wallace (New York City Mayor).

results.title: The Story of Seabiscuit = Pride of Kentucky
results.creator_credit: David Butler, William Jacobs and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Irishman Shawn O’Hara (Barry Fitzgerald), a horse trainer with the gift of being able to tell whether a yearling is going to be a winner or not, arrives in Paris, Kentucky, with his niece, Margaret (Shirley Temple) to take up a position at Millford Farms. He is drawn to a horse called Seabiscuit which initially no-one else credits with winning. At the same time a romance slowly blossoms between his niece and jockey Ted Knowles (Lon McCallister). Margaret is reticent at falling in love with a jockey however as she has already lost her brother, also a jockey, when he fell to his death while riding one of Shawn’s horses. The incident caused uncle and niece to flee their native Ireland. Written by John Taintor Foote. Music by David Buttolph. Filmed in Technicolor.

Margaret is reticent at falling in love with a jockey however as she has already lost her brother, also a jockey, when he fell to his death while riding one of Shawn’s horses. The incident caused uncle and niece to flee their native Ireland. Written by John Taintor Foote. Music by David Buttolph. Filmed in Technicolor.

results.title: The Little shop of horrors [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Roger Corman, American International Pictures (AIP) and Filmgroup
results.brief_description: Originally a film directed by Roger Corman and shot in two days in 1960, then a musical play extravaganza on Broadway in 1982, and finally a multimillion dollar allstar film musical in 1986, “Little shop of horrors,” with its quirkiness, comedy and wonderful satire has developed quite a cult following over the decades. This original version features Jonathan Haze as the nerdy Seymour Krelborn who works in the florist shop near Skid Row, Mel Welles as Mushnik his boss, and Jackie Joseph as Audrey, the shop assistant and woman Seymour secretly desires. When Seymour buys a small exotic plant which suddenly appeared after an eclipse of the sun, strange things begin to happen. Audrey II (Seymour’s name for the plant) takes on a personality of its own and develops quite a unique appetite, wanting to be continually fed, not with plant food, but with blood, and the more it is fed, the bigger Audrey II becomes. This monster plant has an insatiable appetite and the dilemma for Seymour is what can he do about it. Features a cameo by Jack Nicholson in his first motion picture performance as the demented dentist. The legendary Roger Corman made this movie in days and it has more laughs than most big budget films.

results.title: House on Haunted Hill
results.creator_credit: William Castle and Allied Artists Pictures
results.brief_description: Directed in 1958 by 50s B-grade horror maestro William Castle, “House on Haunted Hill” boasted the arrival of “Emergo”, a fluorescent skeleton that swept across the head of audience members in the cinema. Widowed playboy millionaire Frederick Loren (Vincent Price) invites 5 guests: a race driver, a columnist, the previous owner, a psychiatrist, and a typist to spend a night with Loren and his fourth wife, Annabelle, in the haunted house. At the strike of midnight the doors will close, the electricity will be out, and 12 hours lie ahead in a tenement in which there have been several mysterious deaths, including those of Loren’s previous 3 wives. The 4 men and 3 women have nothing in common, other than their need for money, and Loren has posted a reward of $10,000 for anyone who lasts the night. Low in budget, the film boasts several frightening scenes, including an acid bath and dismembered head, earning the film an M rating. Cast includes: Vincent Price, Richard Long, Alan Marshal, Carolyn Craig. Music composed and conducted by Castle collaborator Von Dexter. Remade in 1999 by William Malone.

results.title: It's a wonderful life [DVD]
results.brief_description: The philanthropic director of a small savings and loan association on the verge of bankruptcy in a small American town thinks he is a failure and contemplates suicide. His guardian angel attempts to convince him that his life has been far from worthless. A comedy-drama in a fantasy framework which recapitulates Capra’s major themes: the fragility of good and virtue and the ever threatening encroachment of evil. (Awards: nominated for five Oscars, including Best Picture, Best Director and Best Actor).
